[color=transparent]       [/color]

[align=center][url=https://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=777383][img]https://i.imgur.com/K5V8dPH.png[/img][/url][/align]

[b][color=white]Buddy List Popup Change[/color][/b]
Now you can quickly check the posts or threads of the members who are currently in your buddy list by clicking the "Buddies" link on the top menu. [i][size=x-small][url=https://hackforums.net/showthread.php?tid=5893683]>>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[b][color=white]Youtube 2018 Video Award Contest[/color][/b]
Once again, [url=https://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1][b][color=#9999FF]Omniscient[/color][/b][/url] is offering YouTube 2018 Award in the form of a contest. To earn this award one should make a video on Hack Forums on one of these concepts: Testimonial, Tutorial, and Promotional. Besides, you can also win bytes up to 10K. Grab the chance while you can. [i][size=x-small][url=https://hackforums.net/showthread.php?tid=5905722]>>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[b][color=white]Change Award Order[/color][/b]
There's a new addition to the MyAwards Plugin. Now, members can modify their award order for a contemporary fee of 100 Bytes. Currently, this feature is available for all the members. If you have a lot of fancy awards to showcase, this feature might come handy to you. [i][size=x-small][url=https://hackforums.net/showthread.php?tid=5905145]>>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[b][color=white]Award Market[/color][/b]
One more great feature got introduced for the Awards in addition to the Award Order Feature; Award Market. Now you can also Buy or Sell other members Awards for Bytes. Not all Awards are for sale; some are exempted from the Award Market. Any member can buy the award(s), but one must be [color=#AFAAAA][b]r00t[/b][/color] or [color=#0066FF][b]Ub3r[/b][/color] to sell his Award. Award sale minimum Bytes amount can vary from 1,000 to 500,000 Bytes. To know more about this feature in detail, check the source. [i][size=x-small][url=https://hackforums.net/showthread.php?tid=5905569]>>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[b][color=white]Upgrade Changes[/color][/b]
In the coming week, [url=https://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1][b][color=#9999FF]Omniscient[/color][/b][/url] will be adding Stripe as a Payment method. Now, members will be able to upgrade their profile through Credit Cards. They will also have an option to upgrade their profile to [color=#FFCC00][b]L33t[/b][/color] either on a subscription basis or for a one-time payment. [i][size=x-small][url=https://hackforums.net/showthread.php?tid=5905953]>>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[b][color=white]The Ozone is Well on the way to Making a Full Recovery[/color][/b] 
Some good environmental news for a change. According to a United Nations report, the Ozone layer is on track to being "fully fixed" in the northern hemisphere by 2030. With Antarctica lagging slightly behind in 2060. This level of recovery was all made possible by a global effort called the Montreal Protocol. This forced businesses in 180 separate countries to find more clean alternatives to those chemicals damaging the atmosphere. The results benefits of which we are still reaping. [i][size=x-small][url=https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-46107843]>>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[b][color=white]Cigarette Usage is on the Decline[/color][/b] 
According to a report released by the Center for Disease Control, cigarette usage is at the lowest it has been since they began collecting data of this sort in 1965. Usage has hit "unprecedented lows" according to those at the agency. As the report states, the data collected is "an annual, nationally representative, in-person survey of the noninstitutionalized U.S. civilian population." This is definitely a huge victory on the battlefield of public health. Hopefully, these numbers will continue to fall and fall. [i][size=x-small][url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/11/08/health/cigarette-tobacco-use-study/index.html]>>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[color=transparent]   [/color]

[align=center][url=https://hackforums.net/member.php?action=profile&uid=1034038][img]https://i.imgur.com/lv4d7BY.png[/img][/url][/align]

[b][color=white]The red and blue ripples of the 2018 US midterms[/color][/b] 
6 November 2018 was a huge day in America – the day where citizens are able to execute a highly important and overwhelming civic duty. On this day, it was your traditional United States midterm, seeing that both parties gained seats and both parties lost seats, where Democrats drastically overtook the House. Prior to this midterm, the Republicans held the House, while Democrats held the Senate, although it has now flipped for both sides. Even though all votes have yet to been tallied up, as it stands now, the Republican Party holds 51% of the Senate and the Democratic Party holds 44% of the Senate. As of 10 November 2018, three seats have yet to been declared. Like the Senate race, the race for House seating was initially neck and neck, until Democratic votes started being submitted in astounding numbers. As it stands, 422 of 435 seats have been declared. The Democratic Party holds 51.7% of House seats, where the Republican Party comes in short at just 45.3% currently being held. 

If you were on social media even for a split second within the past few months, there is a significant chance that you were bombarded with demands to get out and vote, and rightfully so. If you have been honored with the ability to make your voice heard by electing an official to represent your views, please do not take it for granted! All of the persuasion on social media most definitely did not go to waste, however; the voter turnout for this midterm’ election reached new highs. Across the United States, “estimated 113 million voters cast their ballots, making this year the first midterm to exceed 100 million votes.” Opposed to the voter turnout in 2014, where only 39% of all registered voters exercised their right, that number increased to 48%. Compared to past elections, a lot of advertisement was displayed on social media, as opposed to the traditional route of running them in between commercial during television shows. This was done in an effort to persuade the younger generation, and it worked. [i][size=x-small][url=https://apnews.com/apf-politics]>>Source[/url][/size][/i] [i][size=x-small][url=http://fortune.com/2018/11/07/voter-turnout-2018-midterms/]>>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[b][color=white]Youth suicides in Japan hit 30-year high[/color][/b] 
As the overall suicide number has continually declined over the past 15 years, suicides “by Japanese youth have reached a 30-year-high, the education ministry said on Monday.” In the month of March 2018, a total of 250 children from elementary school, middle school, and high school have killed themselves; the number increased by five, where last year’s total count was 245, according to a ministry report. The highest since 2018 was in 1986 when 268 students drastically ended their lives. Noriaki Kitazaki, a ministry official, says “the number of suicides of students have stayed high, and that is an alarming issue which should be tackled.” However, it is easier said than done. Finding the root cause of this, seeing that there are many difficult factors behind the increase, some of which they believe are unknown. “Out of the 250 cases, 33 children were reported to have had concerns about their future, 31 had family problems, 10 were bullied, while 140 were unknown, the survey showed.”

A report done by the ministry states that some children were dealing with “family problems, worrying about their futures and bullying.” Although schools are confused from this outcome because students did not leave a note like requested. The majority of students who took their lives were in high school, where in Japan they typically attend until they turn the age of 18. In 2015, Japan had one of the highest overall suicide rates, but since preventative measures were implemented, the rate has been steadily declining. According to one report, Japan’s total suicide number in 2017 fell to roughly 21,000, opposed to 2003 which had a peak of nearly 34,500. Despite the dropping numbers of overall suicides, child suicide rates have maintained a relatively high number, and is “the leading cause of death among young people in the country.” [i][size=x-small][url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-suicides/japans-youth-suicides-hit-30-year-high-survey-idUSKCN1NA0BW]>>Source[/url][/size][/i] [i][size=x-small][url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-46096626]>>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[color=transparent]    [/color]

[align=center][img]https://hackforums.news/assets/v4/bravo/technews.png[/img][/align]

[b][color=white]British auction house sells its first AI portrait[/color][/b]
British auction house "Christie's" recently sold their first ever AI portrait for $432,500. The piece was created by a collective of three French students, operating under the name "Obvious". The portrait was generated using a generative adversarial network (GAN). Obvious shaped their network's understanding of portraiture by familiarizing it with a dataset of 15,000 historical paintings, before allowing it to generate its own attempt at a portrait. The team signed the artwork with a snippet from the algorithm before framing it for auction. The algorithm used was developed by Google researcher Ian Goodfellow.[i][size=x-small][url=https://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/2170264/algorithm-painted-portrait-and-it-just-sold-christies-us432500] >>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[b][color=white]Facebook gets hit with big fine after Cambridge Analytical scandal[/color][/b]
The UK Information Commissioner's Office charged Facebook with a $645,000 fine in response to the Cambridge Analytical fiasco. This fine was the maximum amount allowed under the Data Protection Act of 1998. Facebook ran into trouble earlier this year when it was discovered that contractors and employees of Cambridge Analytical, a British political consulting firm, sold psychological profiles of U.S. voters that were created using illegally obtained Facebook user data. The leak is said to contain data from up to 87 million accounts, marking the biggest data leak in Facebook history. Facebook officials are hoping that Cambridge Analytica will grant them access to the data they received now that investigations have been closed. Since the investigation has ended, Facebook has published its second-quarter earnings for 2018, which came up short of Wall Street estimates. [i][size=x-small][url=https://www.cnet.com/news/uk-information-commissioners-office-hits-facebook-with-645000-fine/]>>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[b][color=white]Android app scheme generates millions of dollars in profit[/color][/b]
A company called "We Purchase Apps" was recently exposed for operating a multi-million dollar fraud scheme. The company used a large botnet composed of tracked users to generate fake traffic with the goal of obtaining falsified in-app ad revenue. Since We Purchase Apps was buying preexisting apps with established userbases, the fake traffic was masked by real traffic and revenue data. The company frequently changed the behavior and listing info for the apps to avoid detection from Google's ongoing Play Store monitoring. Google is scrambling to identify these apps and delete them from the Play Store. The apps that have been identified were downloaded more 115 million times.[i][size=x-small][url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/craigsilverman/how-a-massive-ad-fraud-scheme-exploited-android-phones-to] >>Source[/url][/size][/i]

[color=transparent]       [/color]

[align=center][color=#95a7c4][size=small]TOPIC:[/size] [i][size=large]What do you think about Bytes, gambling and the impact they've had on the community. How often have you been gambling?[/size][/i][/color][/align]

[size=medium][color=#fff]"Seems fun - creates activity and a discussion-filled topic around the forum, however, also generates a lot of spam and unwanted posting, solely to get a Byte or two from your post."[/color][/size]
~[i][color=#888888]Anonymous[/color][/i]

[size=medium][color=#fff]"It's interesting. I like the concepts, but perhaps it could take a toll on the future developments involving bytes if the members aren't diligent enough with their gambling habits. I would love to see a roulette table; even though the odds are not in favor of the price of bytes. I used to gamble a bit, but now I have mostly stopped other than occasionally gambling to get even amounts of bytes."[/color][/size]
~[i][color=#888888]Anonymous[/color][/i]

[size=medium][color=#fff]"It's a smart way to keep the community engaged. Make them addicted to gambling and have them earn the bytes back by posting. In all seriousness, I feel like this just increased the number of low quality posts. Posts should only away bytes if they are high quality."[/color][/size]
~[i][color=#888888]Anonymous[/color][/i]
